description:
Erpetoichthys calabaricus, commonly known as the ropefish or reedfish, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the order Polypteriformes. This species is native to West and Central Africa, primarily found in the Congo River basin and coastal regions of Nigeria.

Erpetoichthys calabaricus is a unique fish species with several distinctive features. It has an elongated, eel-like body covered in thick, overlapping scales that give it a snake-like appearance. The fish possesses a series of dorsal fin spines along its back, which are thought to be remnants of an ancestral bony exoskeleton. These spines can be raised or lowered as a defensive mechanism.

One of the most remarkable characteristics of the ropefish is its ability to breathe air using a specialized organ called a labyrinth organ. This adaptation allows the fish to survive in low-oxygen environments and even venture onto land for short periods, making it a facultative air-breather.

Erpetoichthys calabaricus is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, small invertebrates, and even some small vertebrates. It is known to be a relatively slow-moving and docile fish, often found resting motionless in its natural habitat.

Due to its unique evolutionary history and adaptations, the ropefish is considered a living fossil and an important representative of the ancient Polypteriform lineage, which dates back to the Cretaceous period.
